On Wednesday, April 9, 2003, at 03:02  PM, Mike Clark wrote:

> I tend to write tests that exercise and validate behavior which is not
> necessarily encapsulated in a single class.

Even in this case, your test still has a firm boundary in mind, right?

For instance, you're test won't attempt to validate private states for 
any of the instances under test...

BTW; The terminology I like best for this approach is "cluster-test" 
(Robert Binder?).

> If I were using the inner class approach, I'm not sure which class 
> would contain such tests.

Alas, there are still no one-size fits all solutions (except in the 
T-shirt industry:)

A simplified case where inner-class visibility felt appropriate dealt 
w/ a Money type and rounding rules... Long story short, my test 
needed/wanted access to intermediate states of the amount field & I did 
not want to expose/"un-encapsulate" the amount field w/ a goofy getter 
method...


public class Money
{
	private BigDecimal amount;

	public static class MoneyTest extends TestCase
	{
		public void testRounding()
		{
			...
		}
	}
}
